awd_titl_txt: CPS: Synergy: Adaptive Management of Large Energy Storage Systems for Vehicle Electrification
awd_abstract_narration:
Large battery systems with 100s/1000s cells are being used to power various physical platforms.  For example, automobiles are transitioning from conventional powertrains to (plug-in) hybrid and electric vehicles (EVs).  To achieve the desired efficiency of EVs, significant improvements are needed in the architecture and algorithms of battery management.  This project will develop a new comprehensive battery management architecture, called Smart Battery Management System (SBMS). The research is expected to bridge the wide gap existing between cyber-physical system (CPS) research and electrification industry communities, provide environment-friendly solutions, increase the awareness of CPS, and develop skilled human resources. 

This project will incorporate and enhance a battery management system (BMS) by including battery state-of-charge (SoC) and state-of-health (SoH) algorithms as well as power management strategies on both pack and cell levels.  Specifically, it consists of five main research tasks: (i) design a dynamically reconfigurable energy storage system to tolerate harsh internal and external stresses; (ii) develop cell-level thermal management algorithms; (iii) develop efficient, dependable charge and discharge scheduling algorithms in hybrid energy storage systems; (iv) develop a comprehensive, diagnostic/prognostic (P/D) algorithm with system parameters adjusted for making optimal decisions; and (v) build a testbed and evaluate the proposed architecture and algorithms on the testbed. 

This research will advance the state-of-the-art in the management of large-scale energy storage systems, extending their life and operation-time significantly, which is key to a wide range of battery-powered physical platforms. That is, SBMS will enable batteries to withstand excessive stresses and power physical platforms for a much longer time, all at low costs. SBMS will also serve as a basic framework for various aspects of CPS research, integrating (cyber) dynamic control and P/D mechanisms, and (physical) energy storage system dynamics.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

inst.inst_name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor

por.por_cntn:
Various physical platforms are nowadays powered by 100s/1000s batteries. In particular, and of special importance to the automotive industry, is the transition from conventional powertrains to (plug-in) hybrid and electric vehicles (EVs). Current state-of-the-art needs significant improvements in the architecture and algorithms of battery management before achieving the desired efficiency and performance of EVs. To meet this need, this project has developeed a new comprehensive battery management architecture, called Smart Battery Management System (SBMS). This project attempted to bridge the wide gap existing between cyber-physical system (CPS) research and electrification industry communities, provide environment-friendly solutions, increase the awareness of CPS, and develop skilled human resources. 

This project has incorporated and enhanced a battery management system (BMS) by including battery state-of-charge (SoC) and state-of-health (SoH) algorithms as well as power management strategies on both pack and cell levels.  Specifically, it successfully (i) designed a dynamically reconfigurable energy storage system to tolerate harsh internal and external stresses; (ii) developed cell-level thermal management algorithms; (iii) developed efficient, dependable charge and discharge scheduling algorithms in hybrid energy storage systems; (iv) developed a comprehensive, diagnostic/prognostic (P/D) algorithm with system parameters adjusted for making optimal decisions; (v) built a testbed and evaluated the proposed architecture and algorithms on the testbed, and (vi) recruited and trained a number of students with a combination of theory and practice. 

This project advanced the state-of-the-art in the management of large-scale energy storage systems, extending their life and operation-time significantly, which is key to a wide range of battery-powered physical platforms. That is, SBMS helps batteries withstand excessive stresses and power physical platforms for a much longer time, all at low costs. SBMS is also expected to serve as a basic framework for various aspects of CPS research, integrating (cyber) dynamic control and P/D mechanisms, and (physical) energy storage system dynamics.

 


Last Modified: 12/05/2020
Modified by: Kang G Shin
